Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience in Plant Biology at the University of Louisville
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of Louisville that will provide research training for 6 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013- 2015. The program focuses on plant biology, including plant genetics, development, genomics, molecular biology, ecology, biochemistry, and biotic and abiotic stress. The department of biology includes 5 plant biology faculty who will serve as mentors. Accompanying the research experience will be an extensive array of educational components, including lectures by participating professors, training in scientific writing and presentations, and a series of lectures and group discussions on scientific ethics. A "laboratory rotation" program will give students exposure to techniques and instrumentation used in other labs in the biology department, as will tours of core laboratories in molecular analysis and biological imaging. Weekly meetings, social gatherings, and joint activities with students in existing university summer programs in other disciplines will provide social interactions for interns among themselves, with biology department researchers, and with the broader campus community. The program is advertised nationally and broadly and is focused on schools with limited research opportunities and those serving large numbers of students from groups underrepresented in the sciences. Students are selected based on academic record and other signs of their potential as a scientist. Students are tracked and continually mentored after the program ends to ensure continued success in their scientific career. Assessment of the success of the program will be carried out in a number of ways, including use of the REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://www.louisville.edu/biology/REU, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Mark Running, mprunn01@louisville.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. The primary focus of the program was to provide research experience in plant biology to students interested in scientific careers but have little or no previous research experience. Accompanying the research experience was an extensive array of educational components, including lectures by participating professors, training in scientific writing and presentations, training in scientific ethics, and safety and notebook training. A first-day formal tour of laboratories and talks by PIs gave students exposure to techniques and instrumentation used in other labs in the biology department, as will tours of core laboratories in molecular/biochemical analysis and biological imaging. Weekly meetings, social gatherings, and joint activities with students in other university summer research programs in other disciplines provided interactions for interns among themselves, with biology department researchers, and with the broader campus community. Such meetings also provided opportunities for REU students to present their research in written and oral formats. Students were drawn from both regional and national schools, including  schools that serve a large number of underrepresented groups, schools in urban settings, and schools that have limited undergraduate research opportunities.

Broader Impacts. We provided eighteen total students with immersive research experience and related educational opportunities. Nearly half the students were from groups underrepresented in the sciences, twelve were women, and eleven were from primarily-undergraduate institutions with limited research opportunities. The projects the students undertook covered a wide range of plant biology fields, including ecology, molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, development, and biofuels. Some examples of projects relevant to society included understanding pathways of excess sugar accumulation in plant tissues, which could lead to more efficient ethanol production, increasing the content of compounds with medicinal and nutritional value, understanding infection of plants by fungal compounds, testing conditions for improving the health of helpful fungal compounds, and studying biological and ecological consequences of citizen-run urban gardens in "food deserts". The majority of students in the program have embarked on careers in scientific research.
